description: Electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena.
name: PRINCIPLES II

values.comments:
This course covers electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and
Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of
electromagnetic radiation; and interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and
diffraction phenomena.
Students really enjoyed this course, but noted that this was primarily a reflection of
the exceptional teaching rather than the specific course material. Nonetheless, students
reported learning a lot and found the physics labs to be meaningful.
Students unanimously loved Professor Johnson, consistently describing him as
“amazing,” “phenomenal,” and the “best professor” they have ever had. Students could
not say enough good about him in every area of teaching, including his “engaging” and
funny lecture style, availability to students for extra help, fair grading, clear and concise
communication of the material, and assignment of relevant homework. Students noted
that he “really cares about his students;” he wants them to understand and succeed; and
he is “open to questions and fun.” He had a great ability to interact with his students on a
personal level and regularly asked for feedback on his course. Several students also
noted that he “make[s] physics relevant” and “clarif[ies] concepts by conveying intuition
rather than implying them from math equations.” He uses multimedia, demonstrations,
and actively encourages participation during lectures. Professor Johnson posts his class
notes online, which was an “excellent study aid.”
This course fulfills the Physical World Sector Requirement. Prerequisites for this
course are PHYS 150 or PHYS 170, and corequisites are MATH 114 and PHYS 151
LAB. Exams were described as “challenging yet fair,” and students felt well prepared for
them. Weekly quizzes were also given, and students found that this helped them “stay on
top of the work.” Students recommended this course to anyone considering taking
introductory physics, whether they be a physics major or a non-major taking this course
for a pre-health requirement.
